description: Emotional healing wisdom from Hindu scriptures

teachings.verse: देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा। तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति॥
teachings.translation: As the embodied soul continuously passes through childhood, youth and old age, so does it pass into another body at death. The wise are not deluded by this.
teachings.practice: Meditate on the eternal nature of the Self (Atman). Recognize that what grieves is the ego, not your true Self. Practice Atma-Vichara (self-inquiry): 'Who is sad?'

teachings.verse: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः। उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः॥
teachings.translation: The unreal has no existence; the Real never ceases to be. The truth about both has been realized by seers of Truth.
teachings.practice: Contemplate the difference between the passing (body, emotions) and the eternal (Atman). Practice Sat-Asatविवeka (discrimination between Real and unreal).

teachings.translation: O son of Kunti, the contact between the senses and sense objects gives rise to fleeting sensations of heat and cold, pleasure and pain. They come and go; they are impermanent. Endure them bravely.
teachings.practice: Practice Titiksha (forbearance). Witness sadness as a passing wave. Use the mantra: 'This too shall pass' (इदम् अपि गच्छति).

practices: Japa meditation with 'ॐ शान्तिः' (Om Shanti) - 108 times to invoke peace
Atma-Vichara: Inquire 'Who is experiencing this sadness?' to transcend identification with emotion
Read Chapter 2 of Bhagavad Gita (Sankhya Yoga) on the nature of the eternal Self
Surrender practice: Offer your sorrow to the Divine with 'ईश्वरार्पणं' (Ishvararpana)
Remember: 'अहं ब्रह्मास्मि' (Aham Brahmasmi) - I am Brahman, not this temporary sadness

teachings.verse: क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः। स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति॥
teachings.translation: From anger arises delusion; from delusion, confusion of memory; from confusion of memory, loss of intelligence; and from loss of intelligence, one is ruined.
teachings.practice: When anger arises, immediately chant 'ॐ शान्ति' (Om Shanti) three times. Recognize anger as the thief of wisdom. Practice Pratipaksha Bhavana (cultivating opposite thoughts).

teachings.verse: कामः क्रोधः तथा लोभः स्वर्गद्वारस्य पातनम्
teachings.translation: Lust, anger, and greed - these are the three gates to hell that destroy the soul.
teachings.practice: See anger as a demon (Asura) within. Practice Krodha-Nirodha (anger restraint) through witnessing without acting.

teachings.translation: Equanimity is called Yoga.
teachings.practice: Cultivate Samatva (equanimity). Practice seeing both praise and blame, gain and loss as equal. This destroys anger at its root.

practices: Shama practice: Cultivate calmness through pranayama - Sheetali (cooling breath)
Kshama Bhavana: Practice forgiveness meditation - 'I forgive all, I seek forgiveness from all'
Pratipaksha Bhavana: When anger arises, immediately cultivate love (Priti) and compassion (Karuna)
Chant 'ॐ शं शान्ताय नमः' (Om Sham Shantaya Namah) - salutations to peace
Remember: Anger is Rajas (passion/agitation). Return to Sattva (purity/peace) through meditation

teachings.translation: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and yoga...
teachings.practice: Cultivate Abhaya (fearlessness) through remembrance of your divine nature. You are immortal Atman, beyond all harm.

teachings.verse: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः। अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे॥
teachings.translation: The soul is never born nor does it ever die; nor having once existed, does it ever cease to be. The soul is without birth, eternal, immortal and ageless. It is not destroyed when the body is destroyed.
teachings.practice: Meditate on your immortal nature. Chant 'अजोऽहम्' (Ajo'ham) - I am unborn, I am deathless.

teachings.translation: The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna.
teachings.practice: Remember the Divine resides within you. You are never alone. Practice Ishvara Pranidhana (surrender to the Divine).

practices: Abhaya Mudra: Practice the gesture of fearlessness while chanting 'अभयं सर्वभूतेभ्यो मत्तः' (Abhayam sarvabhutebhyo mattah)
Hanuman Chalisa: Chant this powerful hymn for courage and protection
Mrityunjaya Mantra: 'ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे...' for protection and fearlessness
Contemplate: 'यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र' (Yo mam pashyati sarvatra) - He who sees Me everywhere
Practice Vairagya (non-attachment): Fear arises from attachment; detachment brings fearlessness

teachings.verse: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते॥
teachings.translation: Perform your duty with equanimity, abandoning attachment to success or failure. Such equanimity is called Yoga.
teachings.practice: Practice Nishkama Karma (action without attachment to fruits). Do your dharma and surrender results to the Divine.

teachings.verse: तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च। मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयः॥
teachings.translation: Therefore, remember Me at all times and fight. With mind and intellect surrendered to Me, you will surely attain Me.
teachings.practice: Practice Anusmriti (constant remembrance). Replace anxious thoughts with divine remembrance: 'ॐ नमो नारायणाय'.

teachings.translation: Yoga is the restraint of mental modifications.
teachings.practice: Practice Chitta Vritti Nirodha: Observe thoughts without engaging. They are clouds passing through the sky of consciousness.

practices: Pratiprasava: Reverse the anxiety by tracing it to its source through meditation
Nadi Shodhana (alternate nostril breathing): Balances Ida and Pingala nadis, calming the mind
Japa of 'ॐ नमः शिवाय' (Om Namah Shivaya): Destroys mental agitation
Practice Ishvara Pranidhana: Surrender all worries to the Divine with trust (Shraddha)
Remember: The present moment is all there is. Past and future are Maya (illusion).

teachings.translation: Show me Your cosmic form, O Lord, so that I may see the truth clearly.
teachings.practice: When confused, seek higher vision through prayer and meditation. Ask the Divine within for guidance.

teachings.verse: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति॥
teachings.translation: One who has faith, is sincere, and has mastery over the senses, attains knowledge. Having attained knowledge, one quickly attains supreme peace.
teachings.practice: Cultivate Shraddha (faith) and practice Indriya Nigraha (sense control). Confusion arises from scattered attention.

teachings.translation: The Guru alone reveals the truth and shows the way.
teachings.practice: Seek guidance from a Sat-Guru (true teacher) or from the Guru within. Practice Guru-dhyana (meditation on the teacher).

practices: Viveka (discrimination): Practice discerning the Real from the unreal, eternal from temporary
Svadhyaya (self-study): Study sacred texts like Bhagavad Gita for clarity and wisdom
Antarmukhi Sadhana: Turn attention inward through meditation - answers come from within
Mantra for clarity: 'ॐ गं गणपतये नमः' (Om Gam Ganapataye Namah) - removes obstacles
Practice Nididhyasana: Deep contemplation on spiritual truths until clarity dawns

teachings.translation: Treating pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat alike...
teachings.practice: Enjoy joy but don't cling to it. Recognize it as a temporary wave in the ocean of consciousness.

teachings.translation: One becomes full of bliss through practice.
teachings.practice: True Ananda (bliss) comes from within, not from external objects. Practice meditation to access eternal joy.

practices: Practice Santosha (contentment) - a form of sustainable joy not dependent on externals
Offer your joy to the Divine: 'सर्वं ब्रह्मार्पणं' (Sarvam Brahmarpanam)
Share your joy with others (Dana) - joy multiplies when shared
Remember: External joys are Preyas (pleasant); inner joy is Shreyas (good/beneficial)
Meditate on Sat-Chit-Ananda: Existence-Consciousness-Bliss - your true nature

teachings.verse: सर्वभूतेषु यः पश्येद्भगवद्भावमात्मनः। भूतानि भगवत्यात्मन्येष भागवतोत्तमः॥
teachings.translation: One who sees the Divine in all beings and all beings in the Divine is the best among devotees.
teachings.practice: See the Divine in all. Practice Vishva-Prema (universal love): 'सर्वे भवन्तु सुखिनः' (May all beings be happy).

teachings.translation: Devotees, whose eyes are anointed with the love of God, constantly see the Divine within their hearts.
teachings.practice: Cultivate Bhakti (devotion). See love as divine energy. Practice Hridaya-Dhyana (meditation on the heart).

practices: Practice Maitri Bhavana: Cultivate friendliness and love toward all beings
Chant 'ॐ प्रेमाय नमः' (Om Premaya Namah) - salutations to divine love
Remember: True love is selfless (Nishkama Prema), not possessive
Practice Atma-Drishti: See the same Self in all - this is the foundation of true love
Offer love as worship: 'सर्वे भवन्तु सुखिनः सर्वे सन्तु निरामयाः' (May all be happy, may all be free from illness)

teachings.translation: Om, peace, peace, peace (in the physical, mental, and spiritual realms)
teachings.practice: Chant this mantra to invoke peace at all three levels: Adhibhautika, Adhidaivika, Adhyatmika.

teachings.translation: May all the worlds be happy.
teachings.practice: Cultivate Loka-Kalyana Bhavana (well-wishing for all). Your inner peace radiates outward.

practices: Practice Shama (tranquility of mind) through regular meditation
Upasana of the formless Brahman: Meditate on 'शान्तं शिवं अद्वैतम्' (Peace, auspiciousness, non-duality)
Sandhya Vandana: Practice morning and evening prayers for sustained peace
Japa of Om: The sound of peace itself
Live by Ahimsa (non-violence), Satya (truth), and Asteya (non-stealing) - foundations of peace

teachings.translation: The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings. Be grateful for this divine presence.
teachings.practice: Practice Kritagyata (gratitude). Begin and end each day thanking the Divine for all blessings.

teachings.translation: Food is Brahman (Divine).
teachings.practice: Be grateful for everything - food, air, water. Offer gratitude before eating: 'ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविः'.

practices: Practice Prasada Buddhi: See everything as divine grace (Prasad)
Daily Kritagyata practice: List 10 things you're grateful for each morning
Chant 'ॐ नमो भगवते वासुदेवाय' (Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya) with gratitude
Practice Dana (giving): Gratitude expressed through generosity
Remember: Everything is Ishvara Prasada (divine blessing) - even challenges teach us

teachings.verse: आत्मवत् सर्वभूतेषु यः पश्यति स पश्यति
teachings.translation: One who sees the Self in all beings truly sees.
teachings.practice: Practice Atma-Drishti: See your own Self in all beings. Compassion arises naturally from this vision.

teachings.translation: The wealth of the good is for helping others.
teachings.practice: Practice Seva (selfless service). Serving others is serving the Divine.

practices: Karuna Bhavana: Cultivate compassion meditation - wish relief from suffering for all
Practice Paropakara (helping others) as worship
Ahimsa in thought, word, and deed: Non-harm is the foundation of compassion
Chant 'ॐ सर्वे भद्राणि पश्यन्तु' (May all see auspiciousness)
Remember: 'वसुधैव कुटुम्बकम्' (Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam) - The world is one family
